article.description:
Nicole Powell scored 19 points and the defending
WNBA champion Sacramento Monarchs spoiled the expansion Chicago
Sky's home opener, 76-63 Tuesday.
article.headline: Powell, Monarchs spoil expansion Sky's home opener
article.linkText: Powell, Monarchs spoil expansion Sky's home opener
article.story:
CHICAGO (AP) -- The way Yolanda Griffith sees it, this homecoming
should have happened years ago. Chicago was overdue for a WNBA
franchise.

"This should have been one of the first places they tried to
get a team," said Griffith, the Sacramento Monarchs' center and a
Chicago native.

In its 10th season, the league finally debuted in the Windy City
on Tuesday. But Nicole Powell and defending WNBA champion
Sacramento made it a rough introduction.

Powell scored 19 points and the Monarchs spoiled the expansion
Chicago Sky's home opener, 76-63.

Powell was 8-of-13 from the field and converted a 3-pointer that
made it a 10-point game with 3:50 left.

Rebekkah Brunson finished with 13 points and seven rebounds for
Sacramento. Ticha Penicheiro added 10 points, and Griffith grabbed
nine rebounds.

Chicago's Stacey Lovelace scored all of her team-high 11 points
in the second quarter. Candice Dupree, the Sky's first-round draft
pick, finished with 10 points and five rebounds after scoring 19
points and grabbing six boards in Saturday's season-opening 83-82
victory at Charlotte.

"It was exciting," Lovelace said. "The atmosphere was great.
The fans were great. It's just an exciting atmosphere to play in,
and I think it's going to be great for the city."

After beating Phoenix by 27 in Saturday's season opener,
Sacramento led by about 10 for much of the night and withstood
several pushes by Chicago.

The Sky were within nine -- 64-55 -- after Dupree's layup with
about 4:50 left in the game. Brooke Wyckoff then blocked a layup by
Erin Buescher, leading to a shot clock violation, and converted two
free throws to make it 64-57 with 4:06 remaining. But Powell then
quieted the crowd of 5,112 at the UIC Pavilion with a 3-pointer
that made it 67-57 with 3:50 left.

Penicheiro's 3-pointer made it 72-60 with 2:29 left. The
Monarchs hit 7-of-12 from beyond the arc, while Chicago was 3-of-12
from long range.

"They stuck around a lot," Griffith said. "We have a veteran
team. We won the championship last year. We're always under
pressure. If we continue to keep our composure, I think we'll be
OK."

In a pregame ceremony, 13 girls in different WNBA jerseys lined
up in a pyramidlike formation. League president Donna Orender told
the crowd, "Tonight we prove the sky's the limit," and then
presented principle owner Michael Alter and president Margaret
Stender with basketballs. A girl in a Sky jersey walked to midcourt
and held a ball above her head.

And former Destiny's Child member and Sky part-owner Michelle
Williams gave a rousing rendition of the national anthem.

There wasn't much for Chicago to celebrate after that.

After losing a 16-point lead in the fourth quarter against
Charlotte before escaping with a one-point win, the Sky never were
able to sustain a run.

Chicago trailed by 13 before scoring the final seven points of
the first half to pull to 44-38. But the Monarchs scored the first
six of the third quarter.

"It's kind of a cool draw for the fans to have the returning
champions to start off our (home) season," Wyckoff said. "It kind
of makes sense to me. Why not start with the best?"

Griffith predicted big things for the new franchise -- as in a
bigger arena. Capacity at the Pavilion is 7,500.

"I just think, overall, the fans will build," Griffith said.
"The teams that have been in the league for such a long time were
able to build a fan base. It's just going to take (time). If they
continue to play like they're playing, they'll build support. And
they're going to be selling out, but they're going to have to move
to somewhere bigger."
